Comments_List: I learned all about the details involved in linear regression that I did not know before. These included the connection between orthogonal projections and least-squares regression, ANOVA methods, multivariate distributions, added-variable plots, leverage, VIF's, various model selection criterion, mixed-effect models, and causality.
Model estimation, Model comparison and Idea of projection and causality

Rigorous derivation regarding linear model.
Where each components in R output comes from.
Mainly about linear models in statistics. The geometry perspective is insightful!

I learned a new way of looking at linear models in the form of matrices (compared to previously I had only learned about linear models in the form of summations across vectors/matrices and looking at a specific i observation in the model). I refreshed my knowledge in linear algebra and applied those skills to understanding linear regression in terms of projections and understanding different statistical tests in these terms.
Theories behind multiple linear regression and how they are applied.
This course provides a useful review of linear algebra and introduces fundamental concepts in linear models. Many examples of statistical application are included, which is very helpful.
This course helps me understand some common and seemingly straightforward techniques in more depth, and also, helps me review some of the knowledge in linear algebra which I have forgot...
Linear model
How to derive F and T test. Model selection. Linear mixed model.
The thoughts of using the matrix to solve regression problems.

Linear algebra
Rationale behind least square regression

I can now understand R's regression output, whereas previously it was more or less a mystery to me. I also understand how the chi squared, t, and F distributions originate, particularly within the context of linear regression, and the conditions under which they can be used. Overall, though, I wish I personally had had a more solid grounding in linear algebra and general statistics, so I could have gotten much more out of this course.
This class allows us to view linear models in a way that relies heavily on linear algebra, especially concepts about projection and subspace.

Linear Models explored exactly that: linear models. The course is taught with heavy emphasis on linear algebra and orthogonal projections. Other topics discussed include leverage, mixed effects models, R-output understanding, and multiple regression.
linear model
Linear models
higher level linear model theories.
I think I learn everything about linear models
I learned a lots on theory of linear regression model, and different distributions and mixed effect models.
Basis of linear model, especially the theory behind.
statistics theory
Some linear models selection such as AIC, BIC and so on. Some linear model concept such as projection matrix.
Very good course that combines statistics with linear algebra in a very intuitive way.
strength: very rigorous
Very clear slides; Humorous teaching style; Closely related to programming and application; a wide range of topics.

In the beginning of the semester, I found that the material followed a trend/story-line that I could follow and understand the direction in which the material was taking us. A few classes after the midterm, however, it was harder for me to follow a story-line concerning the material we were covering, which in turn made it more difficult for me to understand the material. It seemed like we were jumping from topic to topic, and it was difficult for me to find the relationship among all the material we were learning.
The lectures were really well organized. Assignments were closely related to course contents. Course workload was just about the right level.

Course contents are explained in detail for the first three fourths of the semester. However, due to lack of time, progress in the last few lectures were too fast, while some other important contents were not covered. Organization of the lectures could be improved.

The lectures are informative and the problem sets (as well as the exams) are more interesting than what I would expect for an ordinary linear model class. Also, the discussion on Piazza is super helpful. It's a bit hard for me to come up with further suggestions... maybe making the preliminary slides as close to the final version as possible (except the whiteboard writing part) will help the students who use laptops to take notes (like me) better organize their notes, so that they can write on the preliminary version and there's no need to transfer to the final version with added slides after class.
Good

Strength: teach the derivation of various concepts in linear regression in details, I will remember it for a long time 
Weakness: topics are hard, strong ability in linear algebra is assumed, which is not clearly mentioned in the sylllabus

As difficult as I found this class, I enjoyed it and how it was taught. My only real point of comparison for it is with my undergraduate linear models experience at Berkeley, and that course, in addition to the theory, offered many opportunities to apply what we learned to real data sets. This course was decidedly theoretical, and although I greatly appreciated the chance to learn this much valuable, foundational theory, some applications might have proven a nice enrichment.
The lecture notes sometimes could be better organized.

I found the course interesting and enjoyed the theoretical perspective of the various statistical methods we investigated. However, it was sometimes hard to understand how information learned in class might be applied to problems.
the lectures are well organized and very clear
the lectures are well organized and very clear
The course materials are too many to fully understand. Maybe more focus?
I think more exercise is better.
The course is relatively hard, so it is better to have a reference book which is very similar to what the professor talks in class. Hence we can learn better than just reading the slides.
Too theoretical, a little bit of difficult.
The homeworks can be more related to the concept which we have learnt in class. The PPT can be better organized.
Yes, I would recommend this course to almost anyone.
Yes if he/she is looking for challenge.
Yes

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student but recommend that they make sure that they understand linear algebra concepts very well beforehand. The beginning of the course does review some of these concepts, but they are very crucial for the understanding of the rest of the course.
I would definitely recommend this course. The course is very well organized that from which one can learn useful and important statistical skills.
Yes. It is very helpful for beginners on data science.
Yes. This will be a useful fundamental course for students interested in statistical techniques. It does help to consolidate my understanding on some seemingly basic concepts.
yes
Yes! Joe is a very intelligent instructor. He showed flashes of humor that delighted the students. The lecture notes are clear and helpful. I really appreciate what he taught in this class.
No, it is too theatrical and lecture notes give no examples

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. But preferably only to a student with Theory of Stat and a linear algebra course fresh in his mind. Linear Models is a foundational course that grants the opportunity to build on other absolute fundamentals at the absolute heart of statistics, primarily stat 542 and linear algebra. Also, David Pollard says all students should take it. And I don't argue with David Pollard.
Very good course to gain knowledge about linear models, with the professor being excellent. So yes.
Yes, this is a very interesting class.
Yes, but students entering the class should have a strong understanding of Linear Algebra.
sure, it is really useful for students who are interested in statistics
sure! it is very useful for students who are interested in statistics
Absolutely yes.
If you have very strong knowledge on linear algebra and statistics, then it is a good course.
Yes very good course for learning linear model.
